kohlberg.title: About Kohlberg's Theory
kohlberg.description: Lawrence Kohlberg's theory of moral development describes how people progress through different stages of moral reasoning. Understanding your current stage can help you develop stronger ethical decision-making skills.
kohlberg.stage1Desc: Right action is that which avoids punishment
kohlberg.stage2Desc: Right action serves one's own interests
kohlberg.stage3Desc: Right action pleases others and wins approval
kohlberg.stage4Desc: Right action upholds law and social order
kohlberg.stage5Desc: Right action follows agreed-upon rights and standards
kohlberg.stage6Desc: Right action follows universal ethical principles
kohlberg.aiWorks1: • Present you with moral dilemmas and scenarios
kohlberg.aiWorks2: • Analyze your reasoning patterns using Claude AI
kohlberg.aiWorks3: • Provide personalized insights into your moral development stage
kohlberg.aiWorks4: • Offer specific recommendations for advancing to higher stages

heinz.title: The Heinz Dilemma
heinz.scenario: A woman was near death from a special kind of cancer. There was one drug that the doctors thought might save her. It was a form of radium that a druggist in the same town had recently discovered. The drug was expensive to make, but the druggist was charging ten times what the drug cost him to produce. He paid $200 for the radium and charged $2,000 for a small dose of the drug. The sick woman's husband, Heinz, went to everyone he knew to borrow the money, but he could only get together about $1,000, which is half of what it cost. He told the druggist that his wife was dying and asked him to sell it cheaper or let him pay later. But the druggist said, 'No, I discovered the drug and I'm going to make money from it.' So Heinz got desperate and broke into the man's laboratory to steal the drug for his wife.
options: Heinz should not steal the medicine because it's against the law and he might get punished.
Heinz should steal the medicine because his wife needs it and he tried to pay for it.
Heinz should steal the medicine because society expects a husband to care for his wife.
Heinz should not steal because laws exist to maintain order, even in difficult situations.
Heinz should steal because the right to life is more fundamental than property rights.
Heinz should steal because preserving human life aligns with universal ethical principles.

officer.title: The Officer and the Draft
officer.scenario: During wartime, a young man named Joe was drafted into the military. However, Joe believed the war was unjust and morally wrong. He had to decide whether to report for duty as legally required or to refuse and face imprisonment.
options: Joe should report for duty to avoid punishment and legal consequences.
Joe should do whatever serves his own interests and safety best.
Joe should report for duty because that's what good citizens do.
Joe should report for duty because the law requires it and laws must be obeyed.
Joe should refuse if his conscience conflicts with legal obligations.
Joe should follow his moral principles about human dignity and justice.

lifeboat.title: The Lifeboat Dilemma
lifeboat.scenario: A ship has sunk and there are 6 people in a lifeboat that can only safely hold 5. The boat is sinking slowly. One person must be removed or everyone will drown. The people are: a doctor, a pregnant woman, an elderly man, a child, a convicted criminal, and a college student.
options: Remove whoever is physically weakest to ensure the others survive.
Remove the person who contributes least to my own survival chances.
Remove the criminal because society views them as less valuable.
Follow established maritime law about who should be saved first.
Make the decision democratically, respecting everyone's equal right to life.
This choice violates human dignity - find another solution or accept shared fate.
